section.name: Illustrative example: research questions to understand suburban dairy systems
section.summary:
Do you think “what income does a cow provide to a farm?” is a good research question? No? What do you think is missing?

Firstly, it’s too general to be really understood. What types of farm are we talking about and where? What breed of cow are we researching? A good research question should be specific and easy for others to understand clearly.

Secondly, simple answers to this question exist already - and so the findings of this vague research question won’t bring any new knowledge or understanding. A good research question should be relevant for the subject and further knowledge.

Thirdly, at its simplest, this question can be answered in 2 minutes by searching online - that’s achievable with just a smartphone and an internet connection, but it’s not suitable for a PhD study, for example. A good research question should be achievable and suitable for the study. 

Let’s look at a real example of a research question from a case study of Dairy Production in India, take this paragraph from Reichenbach et al. 2021:

“In the 1970s’, the Indian government launched a decades-long development program called Operation Flood that focused on dairy production as a vital rural-urban linkage [21]. Operation Flood successfully scaled up rural milk production, marketing and processing through dairy cooperatives and improved infrastructures, to supply urban areas [21]. Thus, taking dairy production in Bengaluru, India, as an example for production systems in an urbanizing environment and a discussion point on social-ecological linkages in the same context, the present study considers urban, peri-urban and rural areas in and around an emerging megacity to tackle the following research questions: do distinct dairy production systems (DPS) coexist along a rural-urban interface and how are they impacted by urbanization? To answer these questions, we surveyed 337 dairy producers in and around the emerging megacity of Bengaluru in southern India.”

Reichenbach M, Pinto A, König S, Bhatta R, Schlecht E. 2021. Dairy production in an urbanizing environment—Typology and linkages in the megacity of Bengaluru, India. PLoS ONE 16(8): e0255791


Reichenbach et al. are interested in agricultural systems that cross or connect rural and urban environments.

Their research questions are clear and easy to understand, and made specific by the addition of the geographic context (Bengaluru, India).

Are there research questions going to further knowledge and understanding? Yes! The questions are broad enough that they will produce findings to contribute to our understanding of farming and urbanization.

Do the research questions seem realistic and achievable? Yes! Their methodology and narrow focus means they could manage to survey 337 dairy producers in a multi-year research project. They also highlight that there is existing literature on the topic, which would inform the study and give it more depth.
